I smiled and rubbed my palms together like I was about to get very greedy. "Let's see," I said, stroking my chin. "I'll be wanting that new Xbox when it comes out next month. And I'll definitely be wanting my own car in about six years, a red Porsche would be nice, and . . ."
paras.cn: 然后他看着我，他脸上的某种表情让我开始笑了起来，这也让他像刚意识到什么似的张大了嘴。“等一下，奥吉，” 他指着我说。“你得答应我你永远不会告诉妈咪任何关于这件事。” 我笑了，搓着手掌，好像我马上要变得非常贪婪似的。“让我想想，” 我抚摸着下巴说。“下个月新Xbox出来时我会想要的。大约六年后我肯定会想要我自己的车，一辆红色的保时捷会不错，还有……”

vocab.ex: He had a worried expression on his face.
Wait a minute, I think I forgot my wallet.

vocab.mean: 搓手掌（常表示期待或贪婪）
vocab.ex: The villain rubbed his palms together as he thought about his evil plan.
He was greedy for power and wealth.
The professor stroked his chin thoughtfully before answering the question.

gram.name: 玩笑式的勒索与协商
gram.pattern: Using a secret as leverage for playful demands.
gram.function: 在爸爸请求保密后，主角通过一系列夸张的、玩笑式的要求（'that new Xbox', 'my own car'），将这个秘密变成了一个可以协商的筹码。这个互动标志着他们之间权力关系的暂时逆转，从父亲安慰儿子，变成了儿子“勒索”父亲。这是一种充满幽默感的亲密互动，显示了他们关系的修复和加深。

example.en: "If you want me to keep your secret," she said with a grin, "it's going to cost you an ice cream."
example.cn: “如果你想让我保守你的秘密，” 她咧着嘴笑道，“那可得花你一个冰淇淋。”

gram.constraints: 是一种通过玩笑来处理敏感话题和加深亲密关系的方式。

paras.en: He started laughing. I love it when I'm the one who makes Dad laugh, since he's usually the funnyman that gets everybody else laughing. "Oh boy, oh boy," he said, shaking his head. "You really have grown up." The part of the song we love to sing the most started to play, and I turned up the volume. We both started singing.
paras.cn: 他开始笑了起来。我喜欢我能把爸爸逗笑的时候，因为他通常是那个逗大家笑的开心果。“哎呀，哎呀，” 他摇着头说。“你真的长大了。” 歌曲里我们最爱唱的部分开始播放了，我调大了音量。我们俩都开始唱了起来。

vocab.ex: His silly jokes always make me laugh.

vocab.mean: （非正式）爱开玩笑的人；喜剧演员
vocab.ex: He's the funnyman of the group, always telling jokes.

vocab.mean: 哎呀（表示惊讶、无奈或兴奋）
vocab.ex: Oh boy, I think I'm in trouble.
Can you turn up the music? I love this song!

gram.name: 强调句型 (I'm the one who...)
gram.pattern: Subject + be + the one + who/that + Verb...
gram.function: 用于强调某个动作的执行者正是某人。'I'm the one who makes Dad laugh' 强调了在这种特定情况下，角色的反转——平时逗乐大家的爸爸，现在被儿子逗乐了，这让主角感到自豪。

example.en: Usually he cooks, but tonight I'm the one who is making dinner.
example.cn: 通常是他做饭，但今晚是我做饭。

gram.constraints: 是一种在对话中进行强调和对比的常用句型。

paras.en: "I'm the ugliest guy on the Lower East Side, but I've got wheels and you want to go for a ride. Want to go for a ride. Want to go for a ride. Want to go for a riiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiide." We always sang this last part at the top of our lungs, trying to hold that last note as long as the guy who sang the song, which always made us crack up. While we were laughing, we noticed Jack had arrived and was walking over to our car. I started to get out.
paras.cn: “我是下东区最丑的家伙，但我有车而你想去兜风。想去兜风吗。想去兜风吗。想去兜风吗~~~~~。” 我们总是用尽全力唱这最后一部分，试着把最后一个音拖得和唱歌那家伙一样长，这总能让我们笑得前仰后合。我们正笑着，注意到杰克已经到了，正朝我们的车走来。我开始下车。

vocab.ex: He jokingly called it the ugliest sweater he had ever seen.

vocab.word: at the top of one's lungs
vocab.ex: The fans were screaming at the top of their lungs.
The opera singer could hold a high note for an impressively long time.
His silly dance made everyone crack up.

gram.name: 象征性地改写歌词
gram.pattern: Altering song lyrics to reflect a personal truth.
gram.function: 通过将原歌词中的“最幸运的家伙”（luckiest guy）改为“最丑的家伙”（ugliest guy），父子俩共同创造了一个只属于他们自己的、充满爱与自嘲的仪式。这个改动将一个可能痛苦的现实，转化为一个充满力量和幽默的自我接纳的宣言，深刻地展现了他们之间的情感联系和面对困境的独特方式。

example.en: She changed the song's chorus from 'I'm leaving you' to 'I'm loving you' to fit her happy mood.
example.cn: 她把歌曲的副歌从‘我要离开你’改成了‘我正爱着你’，以配合她愉快的心情。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过改编来赋予文本全新个人意义的强大技巧。

paras.en: "Hold on," said Dad. "I just want to make sure you've forgiven me, okay?" "Yes, I forgive you." He looked at me gratefully. "Thank you." "But don't ever throw anything else of mine out again without telling me!" "I promise." I opened the door and got out just as Jack reached the car. "Hey, Jack," I said. "Hey, Auggie. Hey, Mr. Pullman," said Jack. "How you doin', Jack?" said Dad.
paras.cn: “等一下，” 爸爸说。“我只是想确认你已经原谅我了，好吗？” “是的，我原谅你。” 他感激地看着我。“谢谢你。” “但以后再也不要不告诉我，就扔掉我的任何东西了！” “我保证。” 我打开门，在杰克刚好走到车边时下了车。“嘿，杰克，” 我说。“嘿，奥吉。嘿，普尔曼先生，” 杰克说。“你好吗，杰克？” 爸爸说。

vocab.ex: Hold on, I think I forgot my keys.
Please make sure all the lights are off before you leave.
It's important to learn to forgive others.
She gratefully accepted the help he offered.

gram.name: 带有条件的宽恕
gram.pattern: Statement of forgiveness + but + [condition].
gram.function: 主角在表达宽恕（'Yes, I forgive you.'）之后，立即用 'but' 附加了一个明确的条件（'don't ever throw anything... again'）。这显示了他的成长：他不仅能够原谅，还能清晰地为自己设定界限，并要求对方尊重。这是一个成熟的情感交流。

example.en: I accept your apology, but don't ever lie to me again.
example.cn: 我接受你的道歉，但以后再也不要对我撒谎了。

gram.constraints: 是一种在解决冲突时建立未来行为准则的方式。

paras.en: "See you later, Dad," I said, closing the door. "Good luck, guys!" Dad called out, rolling down the front window. "See you on the other side of fifth grade!" We waved as he turned on the ignition and started to pull away, but then I ran over and he stopped the car. I put my head in the window so Jack wouldn't hear what I was saying. "Can you guys not kiss me a lot after graduation?" I asked quietly. "It's kind of embarrassing." "I'll try my best." "Tell Mom, too?" "I don't think she'll be able to resist, Auggie, but I'll pass it along." "Bye, dear ol' Dad." He smiled. "Bye, my son, my son."
paras.cn: “待会见，爸爸，” 我说，关上了门。“祝你们好运，孩子们！” 爸爸喊道，摇下了前窗。“五年级那边见！” 他发动引擎开始开走时，我们挥了挥手，但我又跑了过去，他停下了车。我把头伸进窗户，这样杰克就听不到我在说什么。“毕业典礼后你们能别老亲我吗？” 我轻声问。“有点尴尬。” “我尽力。” “也告诉妈妈？” “我想她可能忍不住，奥吉，但我会转告的。” “再见，亲爱的老爸。” 他笑了。“再见，我的儿子，我的儿子。”

vocab.ex: It was hot in the car, so he rolled down the window.
Once you get to the other side of this difficult exam, you can relax.
He put the key in the ignition and started the car.
We waved goodbye as the train started to pull away from the station.
Forgetting his lines on stage was a very embarrassing moment.
I couldn't resist eating another piece of cake.
If you see him, please pass this message along.

gram.name: 用常规对话作结尾呼应
gram.pattern: Ending a scene by repeating a special phrase from earlier.
gram.function: 在经历了充满情感的坦白和协商之后，章节以父子俩标志性的“奥吉狗狗”常规对话（'Bye, dear ol' Dad.' - 'Bye, my son, my son.'）结尾。这种结尾呼应（bookend）不仅标志着他们之间的冲突已完全解决，关系恢复正常，更通过这个充满历史和爱的仪式， reaffirm（再次确认）了他们之间牢不可破的亲密联系。

example.en: They started their journey with a handshake, and after all their adventures, they parted with a final, firm handshake.
example.cn: 他们以一次握手开始了旅程，在经历了所有冒险之后，他们以最后一次坚定的握手告别。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中创造完整感和情感共鸣的有效技巧。

paras.en: Jack and I walked right behind a couple of sixth graders into the building, and then followed them to the auditorium. Mrs. G was at the entrance, handing out the programs and telling kids where to go. "Fifth graders down the aisle to the left," she said. "Sixth graders go to the right. Everyone come in. Come in. Good morning. Go to your staging areas. Fifth graders to the left, sixth grade to the right . . ."
paras.cn: 我和杰克紧跟在一对六年级学生后面走进大楼，然后跟着他们到了礼堂。G夫人在入口处，分发节目单并告诉孩子们该去哪里。“五年级学生沿过道往左走，” 她说。“六年级学生往右走。大家请进。请进。早上好。去你们的集结区。五年级往左，六年级往右……”

vocab.ex: He was running so fast I couldn't keep up, but his little brother was right behind him.
The school's graduation ceremony was held in the auditorium.
The teacher will hand out the worksheets at the beginning of class.
The bride walked gracefully down the aisle.
The soldiers gathered in the staging area before the mission.

gram.name: 用于人群控制的重复指令
gram.pattern: Repetition of short, directional commands.
gram.function: 通过重复简短、清晰的指令（'Come in. Come in.', 'Fifth graders to the left, sixth grade to the right'），Mrs. G有效地管理着涌入礼堂的学生人流。这种重复在嘈杂的环境中是必要的，以确保每个人都能听到并理解指示。

example.en: "Move along, please, move along!" the security guard shouted into the crowd.
example.cn: “请继续前进，继续前进！” 保安对着人群喊道。

gram.constraints: 是一种在管理大量人群时常见的沟通策略。

paras.en: The auditorium was huge inside. Big sparkly chandeliers. Red velvet walls. Rows and rows and rows of cushioned seats leading up to the giant stage. We walked down the wide aisle and followed the signs to the fifth-grade staging area, which was in a big room to the left of the stage. Inside were four rows of folding chairs facing the front of the room, which is where Ms. Rubin was standing, waving us in as soon as we walked in the room.
paras.cn: 礼堂内部非常巨大。大大的、闪闪发光的水晶吊灯。红色的天鹅绒墙壁。一排排排的软垫座位一直延伸到巨大的舞台。我们走下宽阔的过道，跟着指示牌来到了五年级的集结区，那是在舞台左边的一个大房间里。里面有四排折叠椅，面向房间的前方，鲁宾女士就站在那里，我们一进房间她就向我们挥手示意。

vocab.ex: She wore a sparkly dress to the New Year's Eve party.
A magnificent crystal chandelier hung from the ceiling of the ballroom.
The old theater had seats covered in red velvet.
He sank into the soft, cushioned armchair.
We need to set up fifty folding chairs for the event.

gram.name: 连接词省略（用于生动描述）
gram.pattern: A series of descriptive noun phrases without conjunctions.
gram.function: 通过省略并列连词，作者用一系列快速、碎片化的名词短语（'Big sparkly chandeliers. Red velvet walls. Rows and rows...'）来描绘礼堂的景象。这种手法（asyndeton）模仿了眼睛快速扫视一个新环境时捕捉到的视觉印象，使描述更具冲击力和画面感。

example.en: The scene was chaotic. Screaming people. Flashing lights. Overturned cars.
example.cn: 场面一片混乱。尖叫的人群。闪烁的灯光。翻倒的汽车。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过省略来增强节奏感和画面感的修辞技巧。

paras.en: "Okay, kids, take your seats. Take your seats," she was saying, pointing to the rows of chairs. "Don't forget, you're sitting alphabetically. Come on, everybody, take your seats." Not too many kids had arrived yet, though, and the ones who had weren't listening to her. Me and Jack were swordfighting with our rolled-up programs.
paras.cn: “好了，孩子们，坐下。请坐，” 她说着，指着那一排排椅子。“别忘了，你们是按字母顺序坐的。快点，各位，请坐。” 不过，还没到太多孩子，而那些已经到了的也没在听她说话。我和杰克正用我们卷起来的节目单玩击剑游戏。

vocab.ex: The audience began to take their seats as the show was about to start.
The files are organized alphabetically by last name.
The two actors had to learn how to swordfight for the movie.
He used a rolled-up newspaper to swat the fly.

gram.name: 'the ones' 作为代词
gram.pattern: the ones + who/that + clause
gram.function: 用于指代前面已经提到过的一群人或物中的特定一部分。'the ones who had' 指的是“那些已经到了的（孩子们）”，避免了重复名词 'kids'，使句子更简洁。

example.en: I like all the cookies, but the ones with chocolate chips are my favorite.
example.cn: 我喜欢所有的饼干，但带巧克力片的那些是我的最爱。

gram.constraints: 是 'the people/things' 的一个常用替代说法。

paras.en: "Hey, guys." It was Summer walking over to us. She was wearing a light pink dress and, I think, a little makeup. "Wow, Summer, you look awesome," I told her, because she really did. "Really? Thanks, you do, too, Auggie." "Yeah, you look okay, Summer," said Jack, kind of matter of- factly. And for the first time, I realized that Jack had a crush on her.
paras.cn: “嘿，伙计们。” 是萨默向我们走来。她穿着一件淡粉色的连衣裙，而且，我想，还化了点妆。“哇，萨默，你看起来棒极了，” 我告诉她，因为她确实如此。“真的吗？谢谢，你也是，奥吉。” “嗯，你看起来还行，萨默，” 杰克有点就事论事地说。也是第一次，我意识到杰克对她有好感。

vocab.ex: We had an awesome time at the concert.
A: 'You look great today!' B: 'Thanks, you do, too!'
She stated the bad news matter-of-factly, without any emotion.
He tried sushi for the first time and loved it.
She had a huge crush on the lead singer of the band.

gram.name: 对比性的恭维
gram.pattern: An enthusiastic compliment vs. an understated one.
gram.function: 通过对比奥吉热情洋溢的赞美（'you look awesome'）和杰克冷静、低调的回应（'you look okay'），作者巧妙地暗示了杰克的真实感受。这种不自然的、刻意压抑的赞美，反而让主角“顿悟”了杰克内心的真实情感（'had a crush on her'）。

example.en: While everyone else cheered loudly, he just gave a small, quiet nod of approval.
example.cn: 当其他所有人都大声欢呼时，他只是轻微而安静地点了点头表示赞同。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行为反差来揭示角色内心世界的技巧。

paras.en: "This is so exciting, isn't it?" said Summer. "Yeah, kind of," I answered, nodding. "Oh man, look at this program," said Jack, scratching his forehead. "We're going to be here all freakin' day." I looked at my program. Headmaster's Opening Remarks: Dr. Harold Jansen Middle-School Director's Address: Mr. Lawrence Tushman "Light and Day": Middle-School Choir Fifth-Grade Student Commencement Address: Ximena Chin Pachelbel: "Canon in D": Middle-School Chamber Music Ensemble Sixth-Grade Student Commencement Address: Mark Antoniak "Under Pressure": Middle-School Choir Middle-School Dean's Address: Ms. Jennifer Rubin Awards Presentation (see back) Roll Call of Names
paras.cn: “这太令人兴奋了，不是吗？” 萨默说。“嗯，有点吧，” 我点着头回答。“哦天哪，看看这个节目单，” 杰克挠着额头说。“我们得在这里待上一整天了。” 我看了看我的节目单。校长开幕致辞：哈罗德·詹森博士 初中部主任讲话：劳伦斯·塔什曼先生 《光与日》：初中合唱团 五年级学生毕业致辞：西梅纳·陈 帕赫贝尔：《D大调卡农》：初中室内乐团 六年级学生毕业致辞：马克·安东尼奥克 《压力之下》：初中合唱团 初中部主任讲话：詹妮弗·鲁宾女士 颁奖典礼（见背面） 宣读姓名

vocab.ex: I'm kind of tired today.
He scratched his forehead, trying to remember the answer.
This is a freakin' amazing movie!
The headmaster gave a speech at the graduation ceremony.
A famous author was invited to give the commencement address.
The string quartet played a beautiful piece of chamber music.
He plays the cello in a string ensemble.

gram.name: 叙事中的列表格式
gram.pattern: Using line breaks and capitalization to present a list.
gram.function: 作者没有用一个长句子来描述节目单的内容，而是直接将其以列表的形式呈现出来。这种格式上的变化打破了常规的段落结构，不仅清晰地展示了典礼的冗长流程，也让读者能直观地感受到杰克为什么会抱怨“得在这里待上一整天”。

example.en: My shopping list was simple: Milk, Bread, Eggs.
example.cn: 我的购物清单很简单：牛奶、面包、鸡蛋。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过视觉格式来传达信息的有效技巧。

paras.en: "Why do you think that?" I asked. "Because Mr. Jansen's speeches go on forever," said Jack. "He's even worse than Tushman!" "My mom said she actually dozed off when he spoke last year," Summer added. "What's the awards presentation?" I asked. "That's where they give medals to the biggest brainiacs," Jack answered. "Which would mean Charlotte and Ximena will win everything in the fifth grade, like they won everything in the fourth grade and in the third grade." "Not in the second grade?" I laughed. "They didn't give those awards out in the second grade," he answered. "Maybe you'll win this year," I joked. "Not unless they give awards for the most Cs!" he laughed.
paras.cn: “你为什么那么想？” 我问。“因为詹森先生的演讲没完没了，” 杰克说。“他甚至比塔什曼还糟！” “我妈妈说她去年听他讲话时居然打瞌睡了，” 萨默补充道。“颁奖典礼是什么？” 我问。“那是他们给最牛的学霸发奖牌的地方，” 杰克回答。“那就意味着夏洛特和西梅纳会赢得五年级的所有奖项，就像她们赢得四年级和三年级的所有奖项一样。” “二年级没赢？” 我笑了。“他们二年级不颁那些奖，” 他回答。“也许你今年会赢，” 我开玩笑说。“除非他们给得C最多的人颁奖！” 他笑道。

vocab.ex: The meeting seemed to go on forever.
Several students started to doze off during the long lecture.
She proudly wore the gold medal she had won.
She's a total brainiac who gets straight A's in every subject.
I won't go unless you come with me.

gram.name: 自嘲式幽默
gram.pattern: Making a joke at one's own expense.
gram.function: 当奥吉开玩笑说他可能会赢奖时，杰克用一句自嘲的话（'Not unless they give awards for the most Cs!'）来回应。这种幽默方式通过贬低自己来制造笑点，不仅展现了杰克的谦虚和风趣，也体现了朋友之间轻松、融洽的关系。

example.en: A: "You're a great cook!" B: "Only if you like burnt food!"
example.cn: A：“你真是个大厨！” B：“前提是你喜欢吃糊了的食物！”

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、建立亲近感的社交技巧。

paras.en: "Everybody, take your seats!" Ms. Rubin started yelling louder now, like she was getting annoyed that nobody was listening. "We have a lot to get through, so take your seats. Don't forget you're sitting in alphabetical order! A through G is the first row! H through N is the second row; O through Q is the third row; R through Z is the last row. Let's go, people." "We should go sit down," said Summer, walking toward the front section. "You guys are definitely coming over my house after this, right?" I called out after her. "Definitely!" she said, taking her seat next to Ximena Chin.
paras.cn: “各位，请坐！” 鲁宾女士现在开始更大声地喊，好像她因为没人听而感到恼火了。“我们有很多流程要走，所以请坐好。别忘了你们是按字母顺序坐的！A到G是第一排！H到N是第二排；O到Q是第三排；R到Z是最后一排。快点，各位。” “我们该去坐下了，” 萨默说，朝前面的区域走去。“你们典礼后肯定会来我家吧？” 我在她身后喊道。“肯定！” 她说，在西梅纳·陈旁边坐下。

vocab.ex: The coach started to yell at the players to run faster.
We have a lot of work to get through today.
The names on the list are in alphabetical order.
Why don't you come over for dinner tonight?
He called out after her, but she didn't hear him.

gram.name: 分号（用于列举）
gram.pattern: Item 1; Item 2; Item 3.
gram.function: 当列举的项目本身是包含逗号的短语或独立的从句时，使用分号可以清晰地分隔各个项目，避免混淆。老师在这里用分号来分隔每一排的座位安排，使指令更加清晰。

example.en: The trip included visits to Paris, France; Rome, Italy; and London, England.
example.cn: 这次旅行包括访问法国巴黎、意大利罗马和英国伦敦。

gram.constraints: 是一种比逗号更强的分隔符。

paras.en: "When did Summer get so hot?" Jack muttered in my ear. "Shut up, dude," I said, laughing as we headed toward the third row. "Seriously, when did that happen?" he whispered, taking the seat next to mine. "Mr. Will!" Ms. Rubin shouted. "Last time I checked, W came between R and Z, yes?" Jack looked at her blankly. "Dude, you're in the wrong row!" I said. "I am?" And the face he made as he got up to leave, which was a mixture of looking completely confused and looking like he's just played a joke on someone, totally cracked me up.
paras.cn: “萨默什么时候变得这么辣了？” 杰克在我耳边咕哝道。“闭嘴，老兄，” 我笑着说，一边朝第三排走去。“说真的，那是啥时候发生的？” 他低声说，在我旁边的座位坐下。“威尔先生！” 鲁宾女士喊道。“我上次查的时候，W是在R和Z之间，对吧？” 杰克茫然地看着她。“老兄，你坐错排了！” 我说。“是吗？” 然后他起身离开时做的那个表情，一种完全困惑和好像刚开了个玩笑的混合体，把我逗得哈哈大笑。

vocab.ex: Everyone at the party thought the new student was really hot.
He was muttering to himself as he worked.
Last time I checked, you're not the boss of me.
He just stared blankly at the wall, lost in thought.
Her expression was a strange mixture of joy and sadness.
His silly jokes always crack me up.

gram.name: 讽刺性反问
gram.pattern: A question stating an obvious fact to point out an error.
gram.function: 老师的问题 'Last time I checked, W came between R and Z, yes?' 并不是一个真正的问题，而是一种讽刺的方式，用来指出杰克坐错了位置。通过陈述一个显而易见的事实（字母表顺序）并以问句形式结尾，她以一种幽默而权威的方式纠正了错误。

example.en: Last time I checked, the speed limit was 60, not 80.
example.cn: 据我所知，限速是60，不是80。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、用于纠正或批评的非直接方式。

paras.en: About an hour later we were all seated in the giant auditorium waiting for Mr. Tushman to give his "middleschool address." The auditorium was even bigger than I imagined it would be—bigger even than the one at Via's school. I looked around, and there must have been a million people in the audience. Okay, maybe not a million, but definitely a lot.
paras.cn: 大约一小时后，我们都坐在巨大的礼堂里，等着塔什曼先生发表他的“中学致辞”。这个礼堂比我想象的还要大——甚至比维娅学校的那个还要大。我环顾四周，观众席上肯定有一百万人。好吧，也许没有一百万，但肯定很多。

vocab.ex: Please remain seated until the plane has come to a complete stop.
The president will give a televised address to the nation tonight.
The audience applauded loudly at the end of the show.

gram.name: 夸张与自我修正
gram.pattern: Exaggerated statement, followed by a more realistic correction.
gram.function: 叙述者首先使用了一个极度夸张的数字（'a million people'）来表达观众人数之多，然后立刻通过一个更现实的修正（'Okay, maybe not a million, but definitely a lot'）来缓和语气。这种技巧模仿了儿童夸张但又试图保持诚实的思维方式，使叙述听起来更真实、更可爱。

example.en: I waited for an eternity! Okay, maybe it was only ten minutes, but it felt like an eternity.
example.cn: 我等了有一个世纪那么久！好吧，可能只有十分钟，但感觉就像一个世纪。

gram.constraints: 是一种在非正式叙事中常见的、表现人物性格的技巧。

paras.en: "Thank you, Headmaster Jansen, for those very kind words of introduction," said Mr. Tushman, standing behind the podium on the stage as he talked into the microphone. "Welcome, my fellow teachers and members of the faculty. . . . "Welcome, parents and grandparents, friends and honored guests, and most especially, welcome to my fifth- and sixthgrade students. . . . "Welcome to the Beecher Prep Middle School graduation ceremonies!!!" Everyone applauded.
paras.cn: “谢谢您，詹森校长，感谢您那番非常友善的介绍词，” 塔什曼先生说，他站在舞台上的讲台后面，对着麦克风讲话。“欢迎，我的老师同事们和全体教职员工……“欢迎，家长们和祖父母们，朋友们和尊贵的客人们，尤其要特别欢迎我的五年级和六年级的学生们……“欢迎来到比彻预备中学毕业典礼！！！” 每个人都鼓起了掌。

vocab.ex: He gave a brief introduction before the main speaker began.
The guest speaker walked up to the podium to begin her speech.

vocab.mean: （大学或学院的）全体教职员工
vocab.ex: The new policy was discussed by the entire faculty.
The mayor was the honored guest at the charity event.

gram.name: 首语重复法（用于正式欢迎）
gram.pattern: Repetition of 'Welcome...' at the beginning of successive phrases.
gram.function: 通过在欢迎不同团体时重复使用 'Welcome...'，演讲者建立了一种正式、庄重而又充满节奏感的欢迎仪式。这种首语重复法（anaphora）在正式演讲中很常见，用于列举和强调。

example.en: Welcome to our city. Welcome to our home. Welcome to our family.
example.cn: 欢迎来到我们的城市。欢迎来到我们的家。欢迎来到我们的家庭。

gram.constraints: 是一种在正式场合中常见的、用于构建结构的修辞手法。

paras.en: "Every year," continued Mr. Tushman, reading from his notes with his reading glasses way down on the tip of his nose, "I am charged with writing two commencement addresses: one for the fifth- and sixth-grade graduation ceremony today, and one for the seventh- and eighth-grade ceremony that will take place tomorrow. And every year I say to myself, Let me cut down on my work and write just one address that I can use for both situations. Seems like it shouldn't be such a hard thing to do, right? And yet each year I still end up with two different speeches, no matter what my intentions, and I finally figured out why this year. It's not, as you might assume, simply because tomorrow I'll be talking to an older crowd with a middle-school experience that is largely behind them—whereas your middle-school experience is largely in front of you. No, I think it has to do more with this particular age that you are right now, this particular moment in your lives that, even after twenty years of my being around students this age, still moves me. Because you're at the cusp, kids. You're at the edge between childhood and everything that comes after. You're in transition.
paras.cn: “每年，” 塔什曼先生继续说，他的老花镜滑到了鼻尖上，他正读着笔记，“我都被赋予撰写两篇毕业致辞的任务：一篇是为今天五、六年级的毕业典礼，另一篇是为明天将举行的七、八年级典礼。每年我都对自己说，让我减少点工作量，只写一篇能用于两种场合的致辞吧。这似乎不应该那么难，对吧？然而，不管我的初衷如何，每年我最终还是写出了两篇不同的演讲稿，今年我终于明白了为什么。这并不像你们可能假设的那样，仅仅因为明天我将对一群更年长的、中学经历已大半成为过去的学生讲话——而你们的中学经历则大半还在未来。不，我认为这更多地与你们现在的这个特定年龄有关，你们生命中的这个特定时刻，即使在我与这个年龄段的学生相处了二十年之后，它仍然让我感动。因为你们正处于转折点上，孩子们。你们正处于童年与之后一切事物之间的边缘。你们正在过渡。

vocab.ex: She was charged with organizing the annual company picnic.
A famous author was invited to give the commencement address.
I'm trying to cut down on the amount of sugar I eat.
He had good intentions, but the plan didn't work out.
Don't just assume you know the answer; check the facts.
My brother loves spicy food, whereas I prefer milder flavors.
His bad mood has to do with the argument he had this morning.
She is on the cusp of a major breakthrough in her research.
The transition from high school to college can be challenging.

gram.name: 修辞结构（否定与肯定）
gram.pattern: It's not [reason A]... No, I think it has to do more with [reason B].
gram.function: 演讲者首先否定一个听众可能会想到的、合乎逻辑但肤浅的理由（年龄差异），然后用 'No, I think...' 引出一个更深刻、更具情感共鸣的真实原因（处于童年的转折点）。这种“先破后立”的结构，使得最终的论点更具说服力和感染力。

example.en: It's not about the money. No, it's about the principle of the matter.
example.cn: 这不是钱的问题。不，这是原则问题。

gram.constraints: 是一种在演讲和辩论中常见的、用于引导听众思路的技巧。

paras.en: "We are all gathered here together," Mr. Tushman continued, taking off his glasses and using them to point at all of us in the audience, "all your families, friends, and teachers, to celebrate not only your achievements of this past year, Beecher middle schoolers—but your endless possibilities. "When you reflect on this past year, I want you all to look at where you are now and where you've been. You've all gotten a little taller, a little stronger, a little smarter . . . I hope." Here some people in the audience chuckled.
paras.cn: “我们今天都聚集在这里，” 塔什曼先生继续说，他摘下眼镜，用它指着观众席上的我们所有人，“你们所有的家人、朋友和老师，不仅是为了庆祝你们在过去一年取得的成就，比彻的初中生们——也是为了庆祝你们无限的可能性。“当你们反思过去这一年时，我希望你们都看看你们现在的位置和你们曾经走过的路。你们都长高了一点，变强了一点，更聪明了一点……我希望如此。” 这时观众席上有些人轻笑了起来。

vocab.ex: A large crowd was gathered in the square.
They went out to a fancy restaurant to celebrate their anniversary.
Winning the championship was a great achievement for the team.
With a good education, you have endless possibilities for your future.
It's important to take time to reflect on your mistakes and learn from them.
He chuckled at the memory of the funny incident.

gram.name: not only... but (also)... 结构
gram.pattern: not only + X + but (also) + Y
gram.function: 用于连接两个并列的、层层递进的成分。'...to celebrate not only your achievements... but your endless possibilities' 将庆祝的意义从对过去的总结，提升到了对未来的展望，使得演讲的主题更具深度和启发性。

example.en: This book is not only informative but also very entertaining.
example.cn: 这本书不仅信息量大，而且非常有趣。

gram.constraints: 连接的成分X和Y应在语法上保持平行。

paras.en: "But the best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average—though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you have touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success.
paras.cn: “但衡量你们成长了多少的最佳方式，不是用英寸，不是用你们现在能绕着跑道跑的圈数，甚至也不是你们的平均绩点——尽管可以肯定，那些事情也很重要。而是你们用你们的时间做了什么，你们选择如何度过你们的日子，以及你们在这一年里触动了谁。那对我来说，是成功的最大衡量标准。

vocab.ex: It's difficult to measure the impact of the new policy.
He ran ten laps around the track for his morning workout.
She worked hard to maintain a high grade point average in college.
The movie was long, to be sure, but it was also very exciting.
His heartfelt speech touched everyone in the audience.

gram.name: 修辞性重定义 (isn't... It's...)
gram.pattern: It isn't [conventional idea]. It's [new, deeper idea].
gram.function: 演讲者通过首先否定一系列传统的、可量化的成长标准（身高、圈数、成绩），然后提出一个更深刻、更具人文关怀的新标准（如何利用时间、触动他人），来重定义“成长”和“成功”的含义。这种结构有效地引导听众从物质层面转向精神和道德层面。

example.en: True wealth isn't about how much money you have; it's about the richness of your relationships.
example.cn: 真正的财富不在于你拥有多少金钱，而在于你人际关系的丰富性。

gram.constraints: 是一种在演讲中提出新观点、挑战传统观念的有力技巧。

paras.en: "There's a wonderful line in a book by J. M. Barrie—and no, it's not Peter Pan, and I'm not going to ask you to clap if you believe in fairies. . . ." Here everyone laughed again. "But in another book by J. M. Barrie called The Little White Bird . . . he writes . . ." He started flipping through a small book on the podium until he found the page he was looking for, and then he put on his reading glasses. " 'Shall we make a new rule of life . . . always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?' "
paras.cn: “J. M. 巴利的一本书里有一句精彩的话——不，不是《彼得·潘》，我也不会要求你们如果相信仙女就鼓掌……” 这时大家又笑了。“但是在J. M. 巴利的另一本叫《小白鸟》的书中……他写道……” 他开始翻阅讲台上一本小书，直到找到他要找的那一页，然后他戴上了老花镜。“‘我们是否该立一条新的人生准则……永远努力做到比分内更善良一点？’”

vocab.mean: （书或戏剧中的）一句台词或话
vocab.ex: My favorite line from the movie is 'May the Force be with you.'
The audience started to clap as soon as the band came on stage.
The story was about a fairy who could grant wishes.
She flipped through the magazine while waiting.
Helping the stranger was being kinder than is necessary, but it made her feel good.

gram.name: 用于幽默的预见性否定
gram.pattern: Mentioning a famous work, then immediately denying it's the one you mean.
gram.function: 当提到作家J. M. Barrie时，演讲者预见到了听众会立刻联想到《彼得·潘》，于是他主动否定了这个联想（'and no, it's not Peter Pan...'）。这种技巧不仅能抓住听众的注意力，还能通过打破预期来制造幽默，并显示出演讲者与听众之间的默契。

example.en: I'm going to quote a famous scientist—and no, it's not Einstein.
example.cn: 我要引用一位著名科学家的话——不，不是爱因斯坦。

gram.constraints: 是一种与听众建立联系、增加演讲趣味性的高级技巧。

paras.en: Here Mr. Tushman looked up at the audience. "Kinder than is necessary," he repeated. "What a marvelous line, isn't it? Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed. Why I love that line, that concept, is that it reminds me that we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness. And what does that mean? How is that measured? You can't use a yardstick. It's like I was saying just before: it's not like measuring how much you've grown in a year. It's not exactly quantifiable, is it? How do we know we've been kind? What is being kind, anyway?"
paras.cn: 这时塔什曼先生抬头看着观众。“比分内更善良，” 他重复道。“多奇妙的一句话，不是吗？比分内更善良。因为仅仅善良是不够的。一个人应该比所需要的更善良。我之所以喜爱这句话，这个概念，是因为它提醒我，作为人类，我们不仅拥有善良的能力，更拥有选择善良的权利。那是什么意思呢？如何衡量呢？你不能用一把尺子。就像我刚才说的：这不像衡量你一年长高了多少。它不完全是可以量化的，对吧？我们怎么知道我们做到了善良？到底什么是善良呢？”

vocab.ex: She has a marvelous talent for painting.
The concept of infinity is difficult for many people to grasp.
He has an amazing capacity for learning new languages.
Test scores are not the only yardstick for a student's intelligence.
The success of the project is not easily quantifiable in terms of money.

gram.name: 苏格拉底式提问
gram.pattern: A series of questions designed to stimulate critical thinking and self-reflection.
gram.function: 演讲者没有直接给出“善良”的定义，而是通过一连串的修辞性和引导性问题（'And what does that mean? How is that measured? ... How do we know...? What is being kind...?'），来激发听众的思考。这种苏格拉底式的提问方法，让听众参与到探索意义的过程中，比直接的说教更具启发性。

example.en: Instead of giving the answer, the teacher asked, 'But what is justice? And how can we achieve it?'
example.cn: 老师没有给出答案，而是问道：‘但什么是正义？我们又如何能实现它？’

gram.constraints: 是一种在教育和哲学探讨中常见的引导技巧。

paras.en: He put on his reading glasses again and started flipping through another small book. "There's another passage in a different book I'd like to share with you," he said. "If you'll bear with me while I find it. . . . Ah, here we go. In Under the Eye of the Clock, by Christopher Nolan, the main character is a young man who is facing some extraordinary challenges. There's this one part where someone helps him: a kid in his class. On the surface, it's a small gesture. But to this young man, whose name is Joseph, it's . . . well, if you'll permit me . . ." He cleared his throat and read from the book: " 'It was at moments such as these that Joseph recognized the face of God in human form. It glimmered in their kindness to him, it glowed in their keenness, it hinted in their caring, indeed it caressed in their gaze.' "
paras.cn: 他又戴上老花镜，开始翻阅另一本小书。“我想和你们分享另一本书里的另一段话，” 他说。“如果你们能在我找它的时候耐心等一下……啊，找到了。在克里斯托弗·诺兰的《时钟的注视下》这本书里，主角是一个面临一些非凡挑战的年轻人。有这么一部分，有人帮助了他：他班上的一个孩子。表面上看，这是一个小小的举动。但对这个名叫约瑟夫的年轻人来说，它是……嗯，如果你们允许的话……” 他清了清嗓子，从书中读道：“‘正是在这样的时刻，约瑟夫在人形中认出了上帝的面容。它在他人的善意中闪烁，在他们的热忱中发光，在他们的关怀中暗示，确实，在他们的凝视中爱抚。’”

vocab.ex: He read a beautiful passage from his favorite novel.
Please bear with me while I try to fix the computer.
She has an extraordinary talent for music.
Helping the old woman cross the street was a kind gesture.
Smoking is not permitted inside the building.
A single candle glimmered in the darkness.
She showed a great keenness to learn.
He gently caressed her cheek.
She felt uncomfortable under his intense gaze.

gram.name: 强调句型 (It was... that...)
gram.pattern: It was + [emphasized part] + that + [rest of sentence]
gram.function: 用于强调句子中的某个特定部分。引文中的 'It was at moments such as these that Joseph recognized...' 强烈地强调了正是“在这样的时刻”，主角才有了深刻的领悟。这种结构使得这个时刻显得尤为重要和具有启发性。

example.en: It was during that difficult time that I discovered my true strength.
example.cn: 正是在那段艰难的时期，我发现了自己真正的力量。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常强力的强调句型。

paras.en: He paused and took off his reading glasses again. "It glimmered in their kindness to him," he repeated, smiling. "Such a simple thing, kindness. Such a simple thing. A nice word of encouragement given when needed. An act of friendship. A passing smile." He closed the book, put it down, and leaned forward on the podium.
paras.cn: 他停顿了一下，又摘下了老花镜。“它在他人的善意中闪烁，” 他微笑着重复道。“多么简单的事情，善良。多么简单的事情。一句需要时给予的鼓励的好话。一个友谊的举动。一个擦肩而过的微笑。” 他合上书，放下它，身体在讲台上向前倾。

vocab.ex: He paused to take a sip of water before continuing his speech.
A single candle glimmered in the darkness.
He needed a little encouragement to try again.
She only had a passing interest in the subject.
He had to lean forward to hear what she was saying.

gram.name: 用于定义的同位语片段
gram.pattern: Noun/Idea. + Noun Phrase. + Noun Phrase. + Noun Phrase.
gram.function: 在提出核心概念“善良”之后，演讲者没有用一个完整的长句来定义它，而是用了一连串的名词短语作为同位语（'A nice word...', 'An act of friendship.', 'A passing smile.'）。这种碎片化的、诗意的列举，将一个抽象的概念分解成一系列具体的、简单的、可感知的行为，使其更具感染力和可操作性。

example.en: That's what freedom is. A long road. A difficult choice. A heavy responsibility.
example.cn: 那就是自由。一条漫长的路。一个艰难的选择。一份沉重的责任。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过列举来深化定义的修辞手法。

paras.en: "Children, what I want to impart to you today is an understanding of the value of that simple thing called kindness. And that's all I want to leave you with today. I know I'm kind of infamous for my . . . um . . . verbosity . . ." Here everybody laughed again. I guess he knew he was known for his long speeches. ". . . but what I want you, my students, to take away from your middle-school experience," he continued, "is the sure knowledge that, in the future you make for yourselves, anything is possible. If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary—the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."
paras.cn: “孩子们，我今天想传授给你们的，是理解那件叫做善良的简单事情的价值。这就是我今天想留给你们的全部。我知道我有点因我的……嗯……冗长而臭名昭著……” 这时大家又笑了。我猜他知道他以长篇大论而出名。“……但我希望你们，我的学生们，从你们的中学经历中带走的，” 他继续说，“是这样一种确信：在你们为自己创造的未来中，任何事都是可能的。如果这个房间里的每一个人都立下一条规则，无论你在哪里，无论何时你可以，你都将努力做到比分内更善良一点——世界真的会变成一个更好的地方。而且如果你们这样做，如果你们的行为比分内更善良那么一点点，那么某个人，在某个地方，某一天，可能会在你们身上，在你们每一个人身上，认出上帝的面容。”

vocab.ex: The teacher's goal was to impart a love of reading to her students.
I want to leave you with one final thought.
He was an infamous criminal, wanted in three countries.
The professor was known for his verbosity, often making a simple point last for an hour.
What is the main point you want the audience to take away from your speech?
I make it a rule to exercise for 30 minutes every day.

gram.name: 用于理想结果的条件句
gram.pattern: If + [condition], + [idealistic result].
gram.function: 通过一个结构清晰的条件句，演讲者将一个具体的、个人的行动（'act a little kinder than is necessary'）与一个宏大的、理想化的结果（'the world really would be a better place'）联系起来。这是一种非常有力的说服和激励技巧，它强调了个体行为的巨大潜力。

example.en: If everyone did their part, we could solve this problem.
example.cn: 如果每个人都尽自己的一份力，我们就能解决这个问题。

gram.constraints: 是毕业致辞等激励性演讲中常见的结构。

paras.en: He paused and shrugged. "Or whatever politically correct spiritual representation of universal goodness you happen to believe in," he added quickly, smiling, which got a lot of laughs and loads of applause, especially from the back of the auditorium, where the parents were sitting.
paras.cn: 他停顿了一下，耸了耸肩。“或者随便你碰巧相信的任何政治正确的、普世良善的精神代表，” 他微笑着迅速补充道，这引来了很多笑声和大量的掌声，尤其是在坐着家长们的礼堂后部。

vocab.ex: When I asked him where the money was, he just shrugged.
He was careful to use politically correct language in his speech.
Yoga is a form of spiritual practice for many people.
The statue is a representation of justice.
The desire for happiness is a universal human feeling.
There were loads of people at the concert.
The performance was met with thunderous applause.

gram.name: 用于包容性的幽默补充
gram.pattern: A serious statement followed by a self-aware, humorous clarification.
gram.function: 在使用了带有特定宗教色彩的“上帝的面容”（the face of God）这一比喻后，演讲者立刻用一个非常现代、自我意识强且略带自嘲的补充（'Or whatever politically correct spiritual representation...'）来扩大其包容性。这种技巧不仅避免了潜在的排他性，还通过幽默的方式展现了演讲者的机智和对多元文化环境的敏感性。

example.en: He wished everyone a Merry Christmas, then quickly added, 'And a happy holiday season to all!'
example.cn: 他祝大家圣诞快乐，然后迅速补充道：‘并祝所有人节日快乐！’

gram.constraints: 是一种在多元化听众面前保持包容性和亲和力的高级演讲技巧。

paras.en: I liked Mr. Tushman's speech, but I have to admit: I kind of zoned out a little during some of the other speeches. I tuned in again as Ms. Rubin started reading off the names of the kids who'd made the High Honor Roll because we were supposed to stand up when our names were called. So I waited and listened for my name as she went down the list alphabetically. Reid Kingsley. Maya Markowitz. August Pullman. I stood up. Then when she finished reading off the names, she asked us all to face the audience and take a bow, and everyone applauded.
paras.cn: 我喜欢塔什曼先生的演讲，但我得承认：在其他一些演讲中我有点走神了。当鲁宾女士开始念获得优等生荣誉的学生名单时，我又开始集中注意力了，因为当我们的名字被叫到时，我们本该站起来。所以当她按字母顺序念名单时，我等着，听着我的名字。里德·金斯利。玛雅·马科维茨。奥古斯特·普尔曼。我站了起来。然后当她念完所有名字后，她让我们都面向观众鞠躬，所有人都鼓掌了。

vocab.ex: I have to admit, I was wrong about him.
He started to zone out during the long, boring lecture.
The discussion became interesting, so I tuned in again.
Her hard work paid off when she made the High Honor Roll.
You were supposed to finish your homework before watching TV.
After her beautiful solo, the violinist stepped forward to take a bow.

gram.name: 用于注意力的短语动词
gram.pattern: Contrast between 'zone out' and 'tune in'.
gram.function: 通过使用一对意义相反的、非正式的短语动词 'zone out' 和 'tune in'，作者生动地描绘了主角在典礼中注意力的波动。这种口语化的表达方式比使用 'lost focus' 和 'started paying attention' 更具画面感。

example.en: I tend to zone out in history class, but I always tune in when the teacher starts telling a story.
example.cn: 我上历史课时容易走神，但当老师开始讲故事时，我总会集中注意力。

gram.constraints: 是描绘心理状态的生动词汇。

paras.en: I had no idea where in that huge crowd my parents might be sitting. All I could see were the flashes of light from people taking photos and parents waving at their kids. I pictured Mom waving at me from somewhere even though I couldn't see her.
paras.cn: 我完全不知道我父母可能坐在那庞大人群的哪个位置。我所能看到的只是人们拍照的闪光灯，以及家长们对他们的孩子挥手。我想象着妈妈在某个地方对我挥手，即使我看不见她。

vocab.ex: I have no idea where I left my keys.
A large crowd gathered to watch the parade.
A flash of lightning lit up the night sky.
I can't picture him as a father.

gram.name: 强调句型 (All I could see... was/were...)
gram.pattern: All + (that) + Subject + Verb + was/were + [emphasized part]
gram.function: 用于强调“唯一”的概念。'All I could see were the flashes of light...' 强调了在混乱的人群中，他唯一能清晰辨认的就是闪光灯和挥手，突显了现场的规模和主角的视角局限。

example.en: I looked at the menu for ten minutes, but all I saw was pizza.
example.cn: 我看了十分钟菜单，但我眼里只有披萨。

gram.constraints: 后面的 'that' 常常被省略。

paras.en: Then Mr. Tushman came back to the podium to present the medals for academic excellence, and Jack was right: Ximena Chin won the gold medal for "overall academic excellence in the fifth grade." Charlotte won the silver. Charlotte also won a gold medal for music. Amos won the medal for overall excellence in sports, which I was really happy about because, ever since the nature retreat, I considered Amos to be like one of my best friends in school. But I was really, really thrilled when Mr. Tushman called out Summer's name for the gold medal in creative writing. I saw Summer put her hand over her mouth when her name was called, and when she walked up onto the stage, I yelled: "Woo-hoo, Summer!" as loudly as I could, though I don't think she heard me.
paras.cn: 然后塔什曼先生回到讲台，颁发学业优异奖章，杰克说对了：西梅纳·陈赢得了“五年级综合学业优异奖”金牌。夏洛特得了银牌。夏洛特还赢得了一枚音乐金牌。阿莫斯赢得了体育综合优异奖章，我对此真的很高兴，因为自从自然静修之后，我就把阿莫斯看作我在学校最好的朋友之一。但当塔什曼先生为创意写作金牌叫出萨默的名字时，我真的、真的非常激动。我看到萨默在她的名字被叫到时用手捂住了嘴，当她走上舞台时，我尽可能大声地喊道：“喔呼，萨默！”，尽管我想她没听见我。

vocab.ex: The guest speaker walked up to the podium to begin her speech.
The scholarship is awarded for academic excellence.
She proudly wore the gold medal she had won.
Ever since he moved to the city, he has been much happier.
I consider him to be one of my closest friends.
She was thrilled to receive an invitation to the party.
He took a course in creative writing to improve his storytelling skills.
He shouted for help as loudly as he could.

gram.name: 用于真诚强调的重复
gram.pattern: Repetition of an adverb for emotional emphasis.
gram.function: 通过重复 'really, really'，作者极大地加强了主角为Summer感到高兴的情感强度。这种重复传达了一种纯粹的、发自内心的喜悦，突显了他们之间友谊的真挚。

example.en: I am really, really sorry for what I said.
example.cn: 我真的、真的为我所说的话感到抱歉。

gram.constraints: 是一种在口语中表达强烈真情的常见方式。

paras.en: After the last name was called, all the kids who'd just won awards stood next to each other onstage, and Mr. Tushman said to the audience: "Ladies and gentlemen, I am very honored to present to you this year's Beecher Prep School scholastic achievers. Congratulations to all of you!" I applauded as the kids onstage bowed. I was so happy for Summer.
paras.cn: 最后一个名字被叫到后，所有刚获奖的孩子们都在舞台上彼此挨着站好，塔什曼先生对观众说：“女士们先生们，我很荣幸向你们介绍本年度比彻预备学校的学术成就者。恭喜你们各位！” 当台上的孩子们鞠躬时，我鼓起了掌。我真为萨默感到高兴。

vocab.ex: I am honored to receive this award tonight.
It is my pleasure to present our next speaker.
She won an award for her scholastic achievements.
The company is looking for high achievers to join their team.
Congratulations on your graduation!

gram.name: 正式称谓
gram.pattern: 'Ladies and gentlemen...'
gram.function: 使用 'Ladies and gentlemen' 作为演讲的开场白，是一种非常标准和正式的方式来称呼观众，为接下来的颁奖环节设定了庄重的基调。

example.en: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for coming tonight.
example.cn: 女士们先生们，感谢各位今晚的到来。

gram.constraints: 是公共演讲中的标准用法。

paras.en: "The final award this morning," said Mr. Tushman, after the kids onstage had returned to their seats, "is the Henry Ward Beecher medal to honor students who have been notable or exemplary in certain areas throughout the school year. Typically, this medal has been our way of acknowledging volunteerism or service to the school." I immediately figured Charlotte would get this medal because she organized the coat drive this year, so I kind of zoned out a bit again. I looked at my watch: 10:56. I was getting hungry for lunch already.
paras.cn: “今天上午的最后一个奖项，” 塔什曼先生在台上的孩子们回到座位后说，“是亨利·沃德·比彻奖章，用以表彰在整个学年中在某些领域表现杰出或堪为典范的学生。通常，这个奖章是我们用来表彰志愿服务或为学校服务的途径。” 我立刻就琢磨着夏洛特会得到这个奖章，因为她今年组织了外套募捐活动，所以我又有点走神了。我看了看我的手表：10点56分。我已经开始饿了，想吃午饭了。

vocab.ex: She made a notable contribution to the field of science.
His exemplary behavior was a model for the other students.
Typically, the weather in this region is warm and sunny.
The company decided to acknowledge her hard work with a bonus.
The community award celebrates local volunteerism.
The school organized a coat drive to help the homeless during the winter.

gram.name: 叙事误导
gram.pattern: Leading the reader to expect a certain outcome before revealing a different one.
gram.function: 通过主角的内心独白（'I immediately figured Charlotte would get this medal'）和随后的走神（'I kind of zoned out a bit again'），作者巧妙地将读者的预期引向了夏洛特。这种叙事误导，使得后来真正获奖者的揭晓更具冲击力和惊喜效果。

example.en: Everyone thought the hero would fail. They were wrong.
example.cn: 所有人都以为英雄会失败。他们错了。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中创造惊喜的常用技巧。

paras.en: ". . . Henry Ward Beecher was, of course, the nineteenthcentury abolitionist—and fiery sermonizer for human rights —after whom this school was named," Mr. Tushman was saying when I started paying attention again. "While reading up on his life in preparation for this award, I came upon a passage that he wrote that seemed particularly consistent with the themes I touched on earlier, themes I've been ruminating upon all year long. Not just the nature of kindness, but the nature of one's kindness. The power of one's friendship. The test of one's character. The strength of one's courage—"
paras.cn: “……亨利·沃德·比彻，当然，是十九世纪的废奴主义者——以及一位激烈的人权布道者——这所学校就是以他的名字命名的，” 当我再次开始集中注意力时，塔什曼先生正在说。“在为这个奖项做准备，阅读他的生平时，我偶然发现了他写的一段话，似乎与我之前触及的主题，那些我一整年都在反复思索的主题，特别一致。不仅仅是善良的本质，而是一个人善良的本质。一个人友谊的力量。一个人品格的考验。一个人勇气的力量——”

vocab.ex: Abraham Lincoln is remembered as a great abolitionist.
She is known for giving fiery speeches about social justice.
The preacher was a powerful sermonizer who captivated his audience.
I need to read up on the company's history before my job interview.
While cleaning the attic, I came upon my grandfather's old letters.
His actions are not consistent with his words.
He spent the evening ruminating upon the meaning of life.

gram.name: 破折号（用于同位语）
gram.pattern: Noun — appositive phrase —
gram.function: 用于在句子中间插入一个同位语或解释性短语。'...the nineteenthcentury abolitionist—and fiery sermonizer for human rights—after whom...' 破折号之间的内容是对 'abolitionist' 的补充说明，增加了信息的丰富性。

example.en: My favorite food—a classic cheeseburger with fries—is not very healthy.
example.cn: 我最喜欢的食物——经典的芝士汉堡配薯条——不是很健康。

gram.constraints: 是一种比逗号更具强调意味的标点用法。

paras.en: And here the weirdest thing happened: Mr. Tushman's voice cracked a bit, like he got all choked up. He actually cleared his throat and took a big sip of water. I started paying attention, for real now, to what he was saying. "The strength of one's courage," he repeated quietly, nodding and smiling. He held up his right hand like he was counting off. "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness. And this is what the Henry Ward Beecher medal is about: recognizing greatness.
paras.cn: 就在这时，最奇怪的事情发生了：塔什曼先生的声音有点哽咽，像是他情绪激动了。他真的清了清嗓子，喝了一大口水。我现在开始真正地、认真地听他在说什么了。“一个人勇气的力量，” 他轻声重复道，点着头微笑着。他举起右手，像是在计数。“勇气。善良。友谊。品格。这些是定义我们为人类的品质，并在某些时候，推动我们走向伟大。而这就是亨利·沃德·比彻奖章的意义所在：认可伟大。

vocab.ex: His voice cracked as he talked about his late father.

vocab.mean: （因情绪激动而）哽咽说不出话
vocab.ex: She got choked up during her wedding vows.
He cleared his throat before he began to speak.
He counted off the reasons on his fingers.
Honesty is a very important quality.
His ambition propelled him to success.
We still meet for lunch on occasion.
The coach saw the potential for greatness in the young player.

gram.name: 列举抽象名词
gram.pattern: Noun. Noun. Noun. Noun.
gram.function: 通过将一系列核心的抽象品质（'Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character.'）作为独立的、断续的句子列出，演讲者极大地强调了每一个词的重要性。这种结构在演讲中非常有力，能让听众对每一个概念进行短暂的思考。

example.en: What do we need? Hope. Unity. Action.
example.cn: 我们需要什么？希望。团结。行动。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过节奏和停顿来强调关键概念的修辞手法。

paras.en: "But how do we do that? How do we measure something like greatness? Again, there's no yardstick for that kind of thing. How do we even define it? Well, Beecher actually had an answer for that." He put his reading glasses on again, leafed through a book, and started to read. " 'Greatness,' wrote Beecher, 'lies not in being strong, but in the right using of strength. . . . He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts . . .' " And again, out of the blue, he got all choked up. He put his two index fingers over his mouth for a second before continuing. " 'He is the greatest,' " he finally continued, " 'whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own.' Without further ado, this year I am very proud to award the Henry Ward Beecher medal to the student whose quiet strength has carried up the most hearts. "So will August Pullman please come up here to receive this award?"
paras.cn: “但我们如何做到呢？我们如何衡量像伟大这样的东西？再说一次，那种东西没有衡量标准。我们甚至如何定义它呢？嗯，比彻其实对此有一个答案。” 他又戴上老花镜，翻阅一本书，然后开始读。“‘伟大，’比彻写道，‘不在于自身强大，而在于正确地使用力量……他的力量能振奋最多心灵的人，便是最伟大的人……’” 然后，又一次出乎意料地，他哽咽了。他用两根食指捂住嘴巴一秒钟，然后继续。“‘他的力量，’ ” 他终于继续道，“‘能通过自身的吸引力振奋最多心灵的人，便是最伟大的人。’ 闲话少说，今年我很自豪地将亨利·沃德·比彻奖章颁给那位以其安静的力量振奋了最多心灵的学生。“那么，奥古斯特·普尔曼，请上前来接受这个奖项好吗？”

vocab.ex: Test scores are not the only yardstick for a student's intelligence.
He was leafing through a magazine while he waited.
The secret to success lies in hard work and perseverance.
Her inspiring words carried up the spirits of the entire team.
I hadn't heard from him in years, then he called me out of the blue.
She got choked up during her wedding vows.
And now, without further ado, I'd like to introduce our guest speaker.
She was awarded the prize for best actress.

gram.name: 戏剧性停顿与高潮
gram.pattern: A series of pauses, emotional displays, and a final, revealing question.
gram.function: 在揭晓最终奖项之前，演讲者通过一系列戏剧性的停顿（哽咽、捂住嘴）来极大地增强悬念。他没有直接宣布获奖者，而是通过描述获奖者的品质（'the student whose quiet strength...'）来引导听众。最后，用一个问句的形式 'So will August Pullman please come up here...?' 来宣布结果，这使得整个揭晓过程充满了情感冲击力和戏剧性高潮。

example.en: He paused, looked at the crowd, and said, 'And the winner is...'
example.cn: 他停顿了一下，看着人群，然后说：‘获奖者是……’

gram.constraints: 是一种在颁奖典礼等场合常见的、用于营造悬念的演讲技巧。

paras.en: He paused and shrugged. "Or whatever politically correct spiritual representation of universal goodness you happen to believe in," he added quickly, smiling, which got a lot of laughs and loads of applause, especially from the back of the auditorium, where the parents were sitting.
paras.cn: 他停顿了一下，耸了耸肩。“或者随便你碰巧相信的任何政治正确的、普世良善的精神代表，” 他微笑着迅速补充道，这引来了很多笑声和大量的掌声，尤其是在坐着家长们的礼堂后部。

vocab.ex: When I asked him where the money was, he just shrugged.
He was careful to use politically correct language in his speech.
Yoga is a form of spiritual practice for many people.
The statue is a representation of justice.
The desire for happiness is a universal human feeling.
There were loads of people at the concert.
The performance was met with thunderous applause.

gram.name: 用于包容性的幽默补充
gram.pattern: A serious statement followed by a self-aware, humorous clarification.
gram.function: 在使用了带有特定宗教色彩的“上帝的面容”（the face of God）这一比喻后，演讲者立刻用一个非常现代、自我意识强且略带自嘲的补充（'Or whatever politically correct spiritual representation...'）来扩大其包容性。这种技巧不仅避免了潜在的排他性，还通过幽默的方式展现了演讲者的机智和对多元文化环境的敏感性。

example.en: He wished everyone a Merry Christmas, then quickly added, 'And a happy holiday season to all!'
example.cn: 他祝大家圣诞快乐，然后迅速补充道：‘并祝所有人节日快乐！’

gram.constraints: 是一种在多元化听众面前保持包容性和亲和力的高级演讲技巧。

paras.en: People started applauding before Mr. Tushman's words actually registered in my brain. I heard Maya, who was next to me, give a little happy scream when she heard my name, and Miles, who was on the other side of me, patted my back. "Stand up, get up!" said kids all around me, and I felt lots of hands pushing me upward out of my seat, guiding me to the edge of the row, patting my back, high-fiving me. "Way to go, Auggie!" "Nice going, Auggie!" I even started hearing my name being chanted: "Aug-gie! Aug-gie! Aug-gie!" I looked back and saw Jack leading the chant, fist in the air, smiling and signaling for me to keep going, and Amos shouting through his hands: "Woo-hoo, little dude!"
paras.cn: 在塔什曼先生的话真正进入我脑海之前，人们就开始鼓掌了。我听到旁边的玛雅在听到我的名字时发出了一声小小的开心的尖叫，而我另一边的迈尔斯则拍了拍我的背。“站起来，起来！” 我周围的孩子们说，我感觉到很多只手把我从座位上向上推，引导我到这一排的边缘，拍着我的背，和我击掌。“好样的，奥吉！” “干得漂亮，奥吉！” 我甚至开始听到有人在喊我的名字：“奥-吉！奥-吉！奥-吉！” 我回头一看，看到杰克正领着大家喊口号，拳头举在空中，微笑着示意我继续走，还有阿莫斯用手拢着嘴喊道：“喔呼，小哥们！"

vocab.ex: His warning didn't register until it was too late.

vocab.mean: 拍某人的背（表示鼓励或祝贺）
vocab.ex: The coach patted the player's back and said, 'Good game!'
After they won the game, the teammates started high-fiving each other.
You finished the race! Way to go!
The crowd started to chant the team's name.

vocab.mean: 拳头举在空中（表示胜利或支持）
vocab.ex: She raised her fist in the air after scoring the winning goal.

gram.name: 用于表现不知所措的累积句
gram.pattern: A long sentence with multiple clauses and phrases.
gram.function: 通过一个包含多个动作的长句（'...I felt lots of hands pushing me..., guiding me..., patting my back, high-fiving me.'），作者营造了一种被积极、友好的行为浪潮淹没的感觉。这种累积的结构生动地传达了主角在那个瞬间所感受到的、令人不知所措的善意和支持。

example.en: The little boy ran into the house, dropping his bag by the door, kicking off his shoes, and shouting for his mom.
example.cn: 小男孩跑进屋里，把包扔在门边，踢掉鞋子，大声喊着妈妈。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过句法结构来模仿情感体验的写作技巧。

paras.en: Then I saw Summer smiling as I walked past her row, and when she saw me look at her, she gave me a secret little thumbs-up and mouthed a silent "cool beans" to me. I laughed and shook my head like I couldn't believe it.
paras.cn: 然后我走过萨默那一排时，看到她在微笑，当她看到我看她时，她给了我一个秘密的小小的“赞”，并无声地对我做了个“酷毙了”的口型。我笑了，摇着头，好像我不敢相信这一切。

vocab.ex: He didn't even say hello as he walked past me.
She gave me a thumbs-up to show that everything was okay.
He mouthed the words 'I love you' from across the room.
"I finished the project!" "Cool beans! Let's celebrate."

vocab.mean: 摇头（此处表示难以置信）
vocab.ex: He shook his head in amazement at the magician's trick.

gram.name: 公共场合中的亲密交流
gram.pattern: Using non-verbal cues for private communication.
gram.function: 在公共的、喧闹的场合中，萨默通过“秘密的小小的‘赞’”和无声的口型这些非语言的、私密的交流方式，与主角分享了一个只属于他们俩的祝贺时刻。这与周围的公开欢呼形成对比，突显了他们之间深厚、独特的友谊。

example.en: Across the crowded room, she caught his eye and gave a small, secret smile.
example.cn: 在拥挤的房间另一头，她与他对视，并给了一个小小的、秘密的微笑。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过细微互动来展示人物关系的写作技巧。

paras.en: I really couldn't believe it. I think I was smiling. Maybe I was beaming, I don't know. As I walked up the aisle toward the stage, all I saw was a blur of happy bright faces looking at me, and hands clapping for me. And I heard people yelling things out at me: "You deserve it, Auggie!" "Good for you, Auggie!" I saw all my teachers in the aisle seats, Mr. Browne and Ms. Petosa and Mr. Roche and Mrs. Atanabi and Nurse Molly and all the others: and they were cheering for me, woo-hoo ing and whistling.
paras.cn: 我真的不敢相信。我想我当时在微笑。也许是在放光彩地笑，我不知道。当我沿着过道走向舞台时，我所能看到的只是一片模糊的、快乐明亮的脸庞看着我，还有为我鼓掌的双手。我听到人们对我大喊着：“你应得的，奥吉！” “好样的，奥吉！” 我看到我所有的老师都坐在过道边的座位上，布朗先生、佩托萨女士、罗奇先生、阿塔纳比夫人、莫莉护士和其他所有人：他们都在为我欢呼，大喊“喔呼”并吹着口哨。

vocab.ex: She was beaming with pride at her son's graduation.
Without my glasses, the world is just a blur.
After all her hard work, she deserves the award.
You won the race? Good for you!
The crowd was cheering and woo-hoo ing when the band came on stage.
The audience started to whistle and cheer for an encore.

gram.name: 表达不信与抽离感的语言
gram.pattern: Using phrases of uncertainty to describe a powerful experience.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列表示不确定和抽离感的短语（'I really couldn't believe it', 'I think I was smiling', 'Maybe I was beaming, I don't know'），作者深刻地描绘了主角在面对压倒性积极情绪时的心理状态。这种感觉如此超现实，以至于他感觉自己像一个旁观者，无法完全处理正在发生的事情。

example.en: When they announced my name, it felt like a dream. I think I stood up. Maybe I said thank you. I'm not really sure.
example.cn: 当他们宣布我的名字时，感觉就像一场梦。我想我站了起来。也许我说了谢谢。我不太确定。

gram.constraints: 是一种描绘角色在极端情绪下心理状态的有效技巧。

paras.en: I felt like I was floating. It was so weird. Like the sun was shining full force on my face and the wind was blowing. As I got closer to the stage, I saw Ms. Rubin waving at me in the front row, and then next to her was Mrs. G, who was crying hysterically—a happy crying—smiling and clapping the whole time. And as I walked up the steps to the stage, the most amazing thing happened: everyone started standing up. Not just the front rows, but the whole audience suddenly got up on their feet, whooping, hollering, clapping like crazy. It was a standing ovation. For me.
paras.cn: 我感觉自己像在漂浮。太奇怪了。就像太阳正全力照在我的脸上，风在吹拂。当我走近舞台时，我看到鲁宾女士在第一排对我挥手，她旁边是G夫人，她正歇斯底里地哭着——是喜悦的哭泣——全程微笑着鼓掌。当我走上舞台的台阶时，最不可思议的事情发生了：所有人都开始站起来。不只是前几排，而是全体观众突然起立，大声欢呼、呐喊、疯狂鼓掌。是起立鼓掌。为我而起。

vocab.ex: After receiving the good news, he had a floating sensation all day.
The storm hit the coast with its full force.
She was laughing hysterically at his joke.
The entire stadium got up on their feet to cheer the winning goal.
The crowd began to whoop and cheer for their team.
He had to holler to be heard over the loud music.
He was working like crazy to finish the project on time.
The orchestra received a well-deserved standing ovation.

gram.name: 结论性短句片段
gram.pattern: A short, incomplete sentence for climactic effect.
gram.function: 在描述了全体观众起立欢呼这一宏大场面之后，作者用了一个非常简短的、带有顿悟意味的句子片段 'For me.' 来作为段落的结尾。这个片段将宏大的公共事件，聚焦到了主角个人的、深刻的情感体验上，极大地增强了这一刻的冲击力和情感分量。

example.en: He had planned everything for weeks. The flowers, the music, the ring. For her.
example.cn: 他已经为这一切计划了数周。鲜花、音乐、戒指。都是为了她。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过简洁来创造力量的文学技巧。

paras.en: I walked across the stage to Mr. Tushman, who shook my hand with both his hands and whispered in my ear: "Well done, Auggie." Then he placed the gold medal over my head, just like they do in the Olympics, and had me turn to face the audience. It felt like I was watching myself in a movie, almost, like I was someone else. It was like that last scene in Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope when Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, and Chewbacca are being applauded for destroying the Death Star. I could almost hear the Star Wars theme music playing in my head as I stood on the stage.
paras.cn: 我穿过舞台走向塔什曼先生，他用双手握住我的手，在我耳边低语：“干得好，奥吉。” 然后他把金牌挂在我的头上，就像他们在奥运会上做的那样，并让我转身面向观众。感觉几乎像是在电影里看我自己，像我是别人一样。这就像《星球大战4：新希望》的最后一幕，卢克·天行者、汉·索罗和丘巴卡因摧毁死星而受到嘉奖。当我站在舞台上时，我几乎能听到《星球大战》的主题音乐在我脑中响起。

vocab.ex: "Well done," said the teacher, "that's a perfect score."
She proudly wore the gold medal she had won.
Winning a gold medal at the Olympics is the highest honor for an athlete.
The audience applauded loudly at the end of the performance.
The goal of the game is to destroy the enemy's base.

vocab.mean: 死星（星球大战中的武器）
vocab.ex: The rebels planned a daring mission to destroy the Death Star.

gram.name: 用于自我定位的文化典故
gram.pattern: Comparing a personal experience to a famous scene from a movie.
gram.function: 主角通过将自己获奖的场景与他最喜欢的电影《星球大战》中的英雄颁奖典礼进行比较，来理解和消化这个超现实的、压倒性的时刻。这个文化典故不仅为他的经历提供了一个框架，也让他将自己置于一个英雄的角色中，赋予了这一刻史诗般的意义。

example.en: Walking into the surprise party felt like that scene from a movie where everyone yells 'Surprise!'
example.cn: 走进那个惊喜派对的感觉就像电影里每个人都大喊“惊喜！”的那个场景。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过引用共同文化背景来传达复杂情感和意义的有效方式。

paras.en: I wasn't even sure why I was getting this medal, really. No, that's not true. I knew why. It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that whole auditorium. To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid. But hey, if they want to give me a medal for being me, that's okay. I'll take it. I didn't destroy a Death Star or anything like that, but I did just get through the fifth grade. And that's not easy, even if you're not me.
paras.cn: 说真的，我甚至不确定我为什么会得到这个奖章。不，那不是真的。我知道为什么。这就像你有时看到一些人，你无法想象成为那个人会是什么样子，无论是在轮椅上的人还是不能说话的人。只不过，我知道对其他人来说，我就是那个人，也许对整个礼堂里的每一个人都是。不过，对我来说，我只是我。一个普通的小孩。但是嘿，如果他们想因为我做我自己而给我一枚奖章，那也没关系。我接受。我没有摧毁死星或类似的东西，但我确实刚刚熬过了五年级。而那并不容易，即使你不是我。

vocab.ex: After the accident, he had to use a wheelchair.
It's a great car. Only, I can't afford it.
The graduation was held in the large school auditorium.
He just wanted to live a normal, ordinary life.
They offered me the job, and I decided to take it.
It was a tough semester, but I managed to get through it.

gram.name: 用于顿悟的自我修正
gram.pattern: Initial thought (denial/confusion) -> Correction ('No, that's not true.') -> Deeper Realization.
gram.function: 这种结构模仿了一个真实的顿悟过程。主角首先表达了困惑（'I wasn't even sure why...'），然后立即进行自我修正（'No, that's not true. I knew why.'），接着阐述了一个深刻的自我认知——他理解了自己在他人眼中的特殊性。这个过程标志着他从被动接受他人目光，到主动理解并接纳自己社会角色的重大转变。

example.en: I thought I was angry at him. No, that's not true. I realized I was just angry at the situation.
example.cn: 我以为我生他的气。不，那不是真的。我意识到我只是对那种情况感到生气。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中展现角色深刻内心变化的有效技巧。

paras.en: Afterward there was a reception for the fifth and sixth graders under a huge white tent in the back of the school. All the kids found their parents, and I didn't mind at all when Mom and Dad hugged me like crazy, or when Via wrapped her arms around me and swung me left and right about twenty times. Then Poppa and Tata hugged me, and Aunt Kate and Uncle Po, and Uncle Ben—everyone kind of teary-eyed and wet-cheeked. But Miranda was the funniest: she was crying more than anyone and squeezed me so tight that Via had to practically pry her off of me, which made them both laugh.
paras.cn: 之后，在学校后面的一个巨大白色帐篷下为五年级和六年级的学生举行了一个招待会。所有的孩子都找到了他们的父母，当爸爸妈妈疯狂地拥抱我时，我一点也不介意，当维娅用双臂环绕着我，把我左右摇晃了大约二十次时，我也不介意。然后波帕和塔塔拥抱了我，还有凯特姑姑和波叔叔，还有本叔叔——每个人都有点眼含泪水，脸颊湿润。但米兰达最搞笑：她比任何人都哭得厉害，把我抱得那么紧，以至于维娅几乎要把她从我身上撬开，这让她们俩都笑了。

vocab.ex: There will be a small reception after the wedding ceremony.
He was working like crazy to finish the project on time.
The child loved to swing on the playground.
She became teary-eyed during the sad movie.
The little girl was wet-cheeked after her fall, but she was okay.
She gave her old friend a tight squeeze when she saw her.
The puppy was clinging to my leg, and I had to gently pry it off.

gram.name: so... that... 结果状语从句
gram.pattern: so + adj/adv + that + result clause
gram.function: 用于强调程度之深以至于产生了某种结果。'...squeezed me so tight that Via had to practically pry her off...' 强调了拥抱的力度及其导致的后果。

example.en: The music was so loud that we couldn't hear each other speak.
example.cn: 音乐声太大了，我们都听不清对方说话。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常常见的因果关系表达方式。

paras.en: Everyone started taking pictures of me and pulling out their Flips, and then Dad got me, Summer, and Jack together for a group shot. We put our arms around each other's shoulders, and for the first time I can remember, I wasn't even thinking about my face. I was just smiling a big fat happy smile for all the different cameras clicking away at me. Flash, flash, click, click : smiling away as Jack's parents and Summer's mom started clicking. Then Reid and Maya came over. Flash, flash, click, click. And then Charlotte came over and asked if she could take a picture with us, and we were like, "Sure, of course!" And then Charlotte's parents were snapping away at our little group along with everyone else's parents.
paras.cn: 每个人都开始给我拍照，并拿出他们的Flip摄像机，然后爸爸把我和萨默、杰克聚在一起拍了张合影。我们互相搭着对方的肩膀，在我记忆中，这是第一次，我甚至没有在想我的脸。我只是为所有对着我咔嚓作响的相机露出了一个大大的、幸福的笑容。闪光，闪光，咔嚓，咔嚓：在杰克的父母和萨默的妈妈开始按快门时，我一直微笑着。然后里德和玛雅过来了。闪光，闪光，咔嚓，咔嚓。接着夏洛特走过来问她是否能和我们合影，我们就说：“当然，当然可以！” 然后夏洛特的父母和其他所有人的父母一起，对着我们这个小团体不停地拍照。

vocab.ex: He pulled out his wallet to pay for the coffee.
Let's get everyone together for a group shot before we leave.
After winning, he had a big fat smile on his face all day.
The photographers were clicking away as the celebrity walked down the red carpet.
She was snapping away with her new camera all through the vacation.

gram.name: 用于营造氛围的拟声词与重复
gram.pattern: Repetition of sound words.
gram.function: 通过重复使用拟声词 'Flash, flash, click, click'，作者生动地再现了被众多相机拍摄的场景。这种手法不仅模仿了相机的声音，还创造了一种快速、兴奋、如同明星走红毯般的气氛，突显了主角此刻作为焦点的、积极的体验。

example.en: Drip, drip, drip. The sound of the leaky faucet kept him awake all night.
example.cn: 滴，滴，滴。漏水的水龙头声让他整夜未眠。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过声音来构建场景和氛围的有效技巧。

paras.en: And the next thing I knew, the two Maxes had come over, and Henry and Miles, and Savanna. Then Amos came over, and Ximena. And we were all in this big tight huddle as parents clicked away like we were on a red carpet somewhere. Luca. Isaiah. Nino. Pablo. Tristan. Ellie. I lost track of who else came over. Everybody, practically. All I knew for sure is that we were all laughing and squeezing in tight against each other, and no one seemed to care if it was my face that was next to theirs or not. In fact, and I don't mean to brag here, but it kind of felt like everyone wanted to get close to me.
paras.cn: 接着我一转眼，那两个麦克斯过来了，还有亨利和迈尔斯，以及萨凡纳。然后阿莫斯过来了，还有西梅纳。我们所有人都挤在一个紧密的大圈子里，家长们不停地按着快门，就像我们在某个红毯上一样。卢卡。以赛亚。尼诺。巴勃罗。特里斯坦。艾莉。我都记不清还有谁过来了。几乎是所有人。我唯一确定的是，我们都在大笑，紧紧地挤在一起，似乎没有人介意紧挨着他们的是不是我的脸。事实上，我不是想在这里吹牛，但感觉就像每个人都想靠近我一样。

vocab.ex: I was walking down the street, and the next thing I knew, I was on the ground.
The players gathered in a huddle to discuss their strategy.
The movie stars walked down the red carpet at the premiere.
There were so many people at the party, I lost track of who I had spoken to.
The room was so crowded that we were practically sitting on top of each other.
We all had to squeeze in to fit in the small elevator.
He's always bragging about how much money he makes.

gram.name: 关于接纳的最终顿悟
gram.pattern: A concluding statement of realization, softened by a disclaimer.
gram.function: 这个段落的结尾是全书最重要的顿悟时刻之一。叙述者首先用 'I don't mean to brag' 来表现自己的谦虚和对这一新体验的难以置信，然后才说出核心感受：'...it kind of felt like everyone wanted to get close to me'。这标志着他社会地位的彻底逆转，从一个被排斥的对象，变成了一个被渴望接近的中心。这个顿悟是他自我接纳和被社会接纳的最终证明。

example.en: I don't mean to sound arrogant, but for the first time, I felt like I was the best player on the team.
example.cn: 我不是想听起来自大，但这是我第一次感觉自己是队里最棒的球员。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过温和的措辞来表达一个深刻、颠覆性认识的有效技巧。

paras.en: People started applauding before Mr. Tushman's words actually registered in my brain. I heard Maya, who was next to me, give a little happy scream when she heard my name, and Miles, who was on the other side of me, patted my back. "Stand up, get up!" said kids all around me, and I felt lots of hands pushing me upward out of my seat, guiding me to the edge of the row, patting my back, high-fiving me. "Way to go, Auggie!" "Nice going, Auggie!" I even started hearing my name being chanted: "Aug-gie! Aug-gie! Aug-gie!" I looked back and saw Jack leading the chant, fist in the air, smiling and signaling for me to keep going, and Amos shouting through his hands: "Woo-hoo, little dude!"
paras.cn: 在塔什曼先生的话真正进入我脑海之前，人们就开始鼓掌了。我听到旁边的玛雅在听到我的名字时发出了一声小小的开心的尖叫，而我另一边的迈尔斯则拍了拍我的背。“站起来，起来！” 我周围的孩子们说，我感觉到很多只手把我从座位上向上推，引导我到这一排的边缘，拍着我的背，和我击掌。“好样的，奥吉！” “干得漂亮，奥吉！” 我甚至开始听到有人在喊我的名字：“奥-吉！奥-吉！奥-吉！” 我回头一看，看到杰克正领着大家喊口号，拳头举在空中，微笑着示意我继续走，还有阿莫斯用手拢着嘴喊道：“喔呼，小哥们！"

vocab.ex: His warning didn't register until it was too late.

vocab.mean: 拍某人的背（表示鼓励或祝贺）
vocab.ex: The coach patted the player's back and said, 'Good game!'
After they won the game, the teammates started high-fiving each other.
You finished the race! Way to go!
The crowd started to chant the team's name.

vocab.mean: 拳头举在空中（表示胜利或支持）
vocab.ex: She raised her fist in the air after scoring the winning goal.

gram.name: 用于表现不知所措的累积句
gram.pattern: A long sentence with multiple clauses and phrases.
gram.function: 通过一个包含多个动作的长句（'...I felt lots of hands pushing me..., guiding me..., patting my back, high-fiving me.'），作者营造了一种被积极、友好的行为浪潮淹没的感觉。这种累积的结构生动地传达了主角在那个瞬间所感受到的、令人不知所措的善意和支持。

example.en: The little boy ran into the house, dropping his bag by the door, kicking off his shoes, and shouting for his mom.
example.cn: 小男孩跑进屋里，把包扔在门边，踢掉鞋子，大声喊着妈妈。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过句法结构来模仿情感体验的写作技巧。

paras.en: Then I saw Summer smiling as I walked past her row, and when she saw me look at her, she gave me a secret little thumbs-up and mouthed a silent "cool beans" to me. I laughed and shook my head like I couldn't believe it.
paras.cn: 然后我走过萨默那一排时，看到她在微笑，当她看到我看她时，她给了我一个秘密的小小的“赞”，并无声地对我做了个“酷毙了”的口型。我笑了，摇着头，好像我不敢相信这一切。

vocab.ex: He didn't even say hello as he walked past me.
She gave me a thumbs-up to show that everything was okay.
He mouthed the words 'I love you' from across the room.
"I finished the project!" "Cool beans! Let's celebrate."

vocab.mean: 摇头（此处表示难以置信）
vocab.ex: He shook his head in amazement at the magician's trick.

gram.name: 公共场合中的亲密交流
gram.pattern: Using non-verbal cues for private communication.
gram.function: 在公共的、喧闹的场合中，萨默通过“秘密的小小的‘赞’”和无声的口型这些非语言的、私密的交流方式，与主角分享了一个只属于他们俩的祝贺时刻。这与周围的公开欢呼形成对比，突显了他们之间深厚、独特的友谊。

example.en: Across the crowded room, she caught his eye and gave a small, secret smile.
example.cn: 在拥挤的房间另一头，她与他对视，并给了一个小小的、秘密的微笑。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过细微互动来展示人物关系的写作技巧。

paras.en: I really couldn't believe it. I think I was smiling. Maybe I was beaming, I don't know. As I walked up the aisle toward the stage, all I saw was a blur of happy bright faces looking at me, and hands clapping for me. And I heard people yelling things out at me: "You deserve it, Auggie!" "Good for you, Auggie!" I saw all my teachers in the aisle seats, Mr. Browne and Ms. Petosa and Mr. Roche and Mrs. Atanabi and Nurse Molly and all the others: and they were cheering for me, woo-hoo ing and whistling.
paras.cn: 我真的不敢相信。我想我当时在微笑。也许是在放光彩地笑，我不知道。当我沿着过道走向舞台时，我所能看到的只是一片模糊的、快乐明亮的脸庞看着我，还有为我鼓掌的双手。我听到人们对我大喊着：“你应得的，奥吉！” “好样的，奥吉！” 我看到我所有的老师都坐在过道边的座位上，布朗先生、佩托萨女士、罗奇先生、阿塔纳比夫人、莫莉护士和其他所有人：他们都在为我欢呼，大喊“喔呼”并吹着口哨。

vocab.ex: She was beaming with pride at her son's graduation.
Without my glasses, the world is just a blur.
After all her hard work, she deserves the award.
You won the race? Good for you!
The crowd was cheering and woo-hoo ing when the band came on stage.
The audience started to whistle and cheer for an encore.

gram.name: 表达不信与抽离感的语言
gram.pattern: Using phrases of uncertainty to describe a powerful experience.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列表示不确定和抽离感的短语（'I really couldn't believe it', 'I think I was smiling', 'Maybe I was beaming, I don't know'），作者深刻地描绘了主角在面对压倒性积极情绪时的心理状态。这种感觉如此超现实，以至于他感觉自己像一个旁观者，无法完全处理正在发生的事情。

example.en: When they announced my name, it felt like a dream. I think I stood up. Maybe I said thank you. I'm not really sure.
example.cn: 当他们宣布我的名字时，感觉就像一场梦。我想我站了起来。也许我说了谢谢。我不太确定。

gram.constraints: 是一种描绘角色在极端情绪下心理状态的有效技巧。

paras.en: I felt like I was floating. It was so weird. Like the sun was shining full force on my face and the wind was blowing. As I got closer to the stage, I saw Ms. Rubin waving at me in the front row, and then next to her was Mrs. G, who was crying hysterically—a happy crying—smiling and clapping the whole time. And as I walked up the steps to the stage, the most amazing thing happened: everyone started standing up. Not just the front rows, but the whole audience suddenly got up on their feet, whooping, hollering, clapping like crazy. It was a standing ovation. For me.
paras.cn: 我感觉自己像在漂浮。太奇怪了。就像太阳正全力照在我的脸上，风在吹拂。当我走近舞台时，我看到鲁宾女士在第一排对我挥手，她旁边是G夫人，她正歇斯底里地哭着——是喜悦的哭泣——全程微笑着鼓掌。当我走上舞台的台阶时，最不可思议的事情发生了：所有人都开始站起来。不只是前几排，而是全体观众突然起立，大声欢呼、呐喊、疯狂鼓掌。是起立鼓掌。为我而起。

vocab.ex: After receiving the good news, he had a floating sensation all day.
The storm hit the coast with its full force.
She was laughing hysterically at his joke.
The entire stadium got up on their feet to cheer the winning goal.
The crowd began to whoop and cheer for their team.
He had to holler to be heard over the loud music.
He was working like crazy to finish the project on time.
The orchestra received a well-deserved standing ovation.

gram.name: 结论性短句片段
gram.pattern: A short, incomplete sentence for climactic effect.
gram.function: 在描述了全体观众起立欢呼这一宏大场面之后，作者用了一个非常简短的、带有顿悟意味的句子片段 'For me.' 来作为段落的结尾。这个片段将宏大的公共事件，聚焦到了主角个人的、深刻的情感体验上，极大地增强了这一刻的冲击力和情感分量。

example.en: He had planned everything for weeks. The flowers, the music, the ring. For her.
example.cn: 他已经为这一切计划了数周。鲜花、音乐、戒指。都是为了她。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过简洁来创造力量的文学技巧。

paras.en: I walked across the stage to Mr. Tushman, who shook my hand with both his hands and whispered in my ear: "Well done, Auggie." Then he placed the gold medal over my head, just like they do in the Olympics, and had me turn to face the audience. It felt like I was watching myself in a movie, almost, like I was someone else. It was like that last scene in Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope when Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, and Chewbacca are being applauded for destroying the Death Star. I could almost hear the Star Wars theme music playing in my head as I stood on the stage.
paras.cn: 我穿过舞台走向塔什曼先生，他用双手握住我的手，在我耳边低语：“干得好，奥吉。” 然后他把金牌挂在我的头上，就像他们在奥运会上做的那样，并让我转身面向观众。感觉几乎像是在电影里看我自己，像我是别人一样。这就像《星球大战4：新希望》的最后一幕，卢克·天行者、汉·索罗和丘巴卡因摧毁死星而受到嘉奖。当我站在舞台上时，我几乎能听到《星球大战》的主题音乐在我脑中响起。

vocab.ex: "Well done," said the teacher, "that's a perfect score."
She proudly wore the gold medal she had won.
Winning a gold medal at the Olympics is the highest honor for an athlete.
The audience applauded loudly at the end of the performance.
The goal of the game is to destroy the enemy's base.

vocab.mean: 死星（星球大战中的武器）
vocab.ex: The rebels planned a daring mission to destroy the Death Star.

gram.name: 用于自我定位的文化典故
gram.pattern: Comparing a personal experience to a famous scene from a movie.
gram.function: 主角通过将自己获奖的场景与他最喜欢的电影《星球大战》中的英雄颁奖典礼进行比较，来理解和消化这个超现实的、压倒性的时刻。这个文化典故不仅为他的经历提供了一个框架，也让他将自己置于一个英雄的角色中，赋予了这一刻史诗般的意义。

example.en: Walking into the surprise party felt like that scene from a movie where everyone yells 'Surprise!'
example.cn: 走进那个惊喜派对的感觉就像电影里每个人都大喊“惊喜！”的那个场景。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过引用共同文化背景来传达复杂情感和意义的有效方式。

paras.en: I wasn't even sure why I was getting this medal, really. No, that's not true. I knew why. It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that whole auditorium. To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid. But hey, if they want to give me a medal for being me, that's okay. I'll take it. I didn't destroy a Death Star or anything like that, but I did just get through the fifth grade. And that's not easy, even if you're not me.
paras.cn: 说真的，我甚至不确定我为什么会得到这个奖章。不，那不是真的。我知道为什么。这就像你有时看到一些人，你无法想象成为那个人会是什么样子，无论是在轮椅上的人还是不能说话的人。只不过，我知道对其他人来说，我就是那个人，也许对整个礼堂里的每一个人都是。不过，对我来说，我只是我。一个普通的小孩。但是嘿，如果他们想因为我做我自己而给我一枚奖章，那也没关系。我接受。我没有摧毁死星或类似的东西，但我确实刚刚熬过了五年级。而那并不容易，即使你不是我。

vocab.ex: After the accident, he had to use a wheelchair.
It's a great car. Only, I can't afford it.
The graduation was held in the large school auditorium.
He just wanted to live a normal, ordinary life.
They offered me the job, and I decided to take it.
It was a tough semester, but I managed to get through it.

gram.name: 用于顿悟的自我修正
gram.pattern: Initial thought (denial/confusion) -> Correction ('No, that's not true.') -> Deeper Realization.
gram.function: 这种结构模仿了一个真实的顿悟过程。主角首先表达了困惑（'I wasn't even sure why...'），然后立即进行自我修正（'No, that's not true. I knew why.'），接着阐述了一个深刻的自我认知——他理解了自己在他人眼中的特殊性。这个过程标志着他从被动接受他人目光，到主动理解并接纳自己社会角色的重大转变。

example.en: I thought I was angry at him. No, that's not true. I realized I was just angry at the situation.
example.cn: 我以为我生他的气。不，那不是真的。我意识到我只是对那种情况感到生气。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中展现角色深刻内心变化的有效技巧。
